title: Fractures or Dislocations Treatment
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: Call 911 if:
bullets: The person is seriously injured.
You suspect injury to the person's head, neck, or back.
Bone is sticking out of the skin .
Bleeding doesn't stop after several minutes of firm pressure.
Blood spurts from the wound.
Experience loss of feeling at the injured site
Experience loss of warmth beyond the injured area.

sections.heading: 1. Stop Bleeding, if Necessary
bullets: Apply firm pressure to wound with clean cloth until bleeding stops.
If bone is pushing through skin, do not touch it or try to put it back in place .

items: Apply firm pressure to wound with clean cloth until bleeding stops.
If bone is pushing through skin, do not touch it or try to put it back in place .

sections.heading: 2. Splint the Area, if Possible
content: The purpose of the splint is to hold still and protect a wounded body part from further damage.
bullets: Cut away clothing if it cannot be removed without moving the injured body part.

Gently tape the dislocated area or fracture to a rolled-up newspaper, ruler, stick, or a rolled-up piece of clothing with first aid tape. In general, try to include the joint above and below the injury in the splint. As much as possible, avoid moving the injured limb, and never force it or try to twist it back into place.

sections.heading: 3. Reduce Swelling and Prevent Injury
bullets: Apply an ice pack wrapped in cloth or a cold compress.
Elevate the injured area if possible.

items: Apply an ice pack wrapped in cloth or a cold compress.
Elevate the injured area if possible.

sections.heading: 4. Manage Pain and Inflammation
bullets: For pain, give acetaminophen ( Tylenol ), ibuprofen ( Advil , Motrin ),or naproxen ( Aleve , Naprosyn ). Do not give aspirin to anyone under age 18.

items: For pain, give acetaminophen ( Tylenol ), ibuprofen ( Advil , Motrin ),or naproxen ( Aleve , Naprosyn ). Do not give aspirin to anyone under age 18.

sections.heading: 5. Get Medical Help As Soon as Possible
6. Follow Up
bullets: The doctor will X-ray the dislocation or fracture and may realign and set it.
The doctor may apply a splint or cast, or surgery may be required.
